discourse_list.title: Coinbase MIP81 Live Call with Coinbase CFO - Questions Needed ASAP

content.content: Update: Call Announced Join us  this Monday, 2022-09-26T16:30:00Z! Hello! This thread is intended to collect questions for the Coinbase CFO, Alesia Haas, for an upcoming live call in the coming days. We have a short time frame (30-minute call slot) for the call, and all questions will need to be screened by Coinbase’s legal team for us to get a complete answer on air. For questions to be considered, they must be submitted by 17:00 UTC on Thursday, Sept. 22. I have volunteered to moderate and curate the question list for Coinbase as a neutral party and will be using this thread to collect questions. A few additional notes:  Questions covered in this session will be strictly limited to those relating to MIP81. If you have other Coinbase-related inquiries, do not expect them to be addressed during this call and I would ask for some self-reflection on that point before submitting questions here. I will be submitting as many eligible questions as possible to ensure we can have a full conversation. Please note that due to time constraints and potential volume issues, posting a relevant question here does not guarantee it will be asked live. I will do my best to group related questions and cover as much ground as possible. Hopefully this goes without saying, but we can have a spirited round of questions and debates while still respecting the proposal author. It is somewhat rare for MIP authors to host a dedicated public call, and even more rare for that call to bring in the CFO of a large institution. Our actions reflect upon our community, and regardless of your stance on this proposal, being able to have respectful discourse with authors is paramount to the DAO having willing decentralized governance participants.  Hopefully, that covers all our bases . If you are unhappy with the format or how this call goes, I would ask that you direct that frustration toward me as Coinbase has largely followed my suggestions on how to best do this. Let’s put our best foot forward and seize the opportunity to have a hot-button governance proposal discussed with the source!
content.GPT-summary: The post is a call for questions for an upcoming live call with Coinbase CFO, Alesia Haas, regarding MIP81. The author of the post is asking for questions to be submitted by a certain deadline and will be curating the list of questions. The post also emphasizes the importance of respectful discourse and the opportunity for decentralized governance participants to engage with MIP authors.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback
3rd party or author wants to collaborate on proposal
3rd party or author is advertising proposal
None

content.content: AMAZING

Payton, thanks for this effort and coordinating the community’s questions. Understanding that the Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards Program Rate is a negotiated rate for all Participating Institutions and that Coinbase can change the rate at its discretion, I have a few questions regarding standard business practices:   What communication notice (e.g. 30 days notice) can we expect from Coinbase regarding rate changes on the program?   Can we expect a communication regarding the program rate after FOMC meetings in which changes (Increases/Decreases) are made to the Fed Fund Target Rate?   Can you please provide an example of the rewards rate earned on 500mm. Would all the 500mm earn 150bps APY or is it tiered (100mm earns 100bps, 10mm earns 110bps, 10mm earns 120bps, etc)?      MIP81: Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards   Coinbase will pay rewards based on our USDC Institutional Rewards POC program rates:  100bps APY on first 100mm 10bps more APY on each 100mm thereafter Rewards rate will be paid based on the highest tier the client falls into Rewards are not to exceed 150bps APY     Is the USDC Institutional Rewards Program ending at the end of 2022?     MIP81: Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards   USDC Institutional Rewards POC will be in effect until the end of 2022, and the final payment will be made on the subsequent month.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: How does Coinbase profit from MIP81? What are Coinbase’s motivations for this MIP?

Great news! What happens to funds in the event of Coinbase insolvency or bankruptcy? Who is the counterparty to Coinbase in your ideal scenario, given that Maker cannot be a legal entity? What rights and access to funds under custody does Coinbase have and plan to have? Please be exhaustive, definite and binding on these parameters.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal

content.content: My questions here:    MIP81: Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards RFC       We appreciate the color provided by the Growth CU on today’s G&R (Governance and Risk) weekly call about the pre-work/discussions that proceeded the submission of this proposal, and specifically the nuance that this proposal relates to a new product offering at Coinbase that is being prototyped to some extent with MakerDAO.  The latest from Gensler in reaction to the Merge opens up a new front for our consideration!  Should have seen this coming, but honestly I had not been thinking lately about…     I think there are probably lots of questions in that thread already that should be imported to your list. Thanks.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Is Maker, as a client, capped at 1.6Bn or could it add more USDC at its discretion (i.e. PSM continues to grow) Can Coinbase share if there are plans to expand the rewards program beyond custody services? Is adding a withdrawal period (i.e term program) in Coinbase’s product plan?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: @prose11 it’s really amazing that you put this together. I understand that it might be too short notice to do this, but would you consider changing the format so: You collect questions from this thread for the next ~24-48 hours. Questions are condensed by you and submitted as a supplemental DD checklist in writing. ~48-72 hours later, we get written responses back. ~24 hours later, we have a live call to discuss. I think having the benefit of an initial response to our general questions before the call can make live follow-up more engaging and informative for the community. In any event, we should all keep in mind that Coinbase has already provided several answers to community questions in it’s main MIP thread, and I hope we can prioritize questions that leverage this information.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: 0xbocaJ:  ~24 hours later, we have a live call to discuss. I think having the benefit of an initial response to our general questions before the call can make live follow-up more engaging and informative for the community.   Noting that this will likely not be possible on the Coinbase end, as one of the reasons they are able to offer their CFO for this call is with the knowledge that their legal term has reviewed what the responses will be. My personal plan for the call is to submit as many of these questions as possible in hopes that pre-prepared questions can serve as a potential follow up to the answers given live. Happy to have @CB_Institutional correct me if I’ve misconstrued anything, but hopefully that sheds some light on why the question asking format will be somewhat restricted during the call. I apologize if this set up is confusing for the community, basically just trying to ease the friction so the community and Coinbase can benefit from this event.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: wen token?

Well done on getting this together ! Just some questions. So @CB_Institutional is not willing to respond in writing to the questions in the thread? Is this call more of a prepared statement addressing the questions as opposed to more traditional Q&A format?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Not sure, will bring it up. There was some concern about the potential volume, might have a work around for distilling like questions down a bit and porting over the spoken answers. We’ll see what the resources look like and keep you posted
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: Coinbase MIP81: CFO <> Community Questions - Monday, September 26 Public Calls   Coinbase MIP81: CFO <> Community Questions  [image]  Add it to Google Calendar  Join the MakerDAO community as we host Coinbase CFO Alesia Haas for an interview regarding in-RFC MIP81: Coinbase USDC Institutional Rewards.  This will be a one-on-one interview with pre-screened questions. Community questions have been submitted in advance and reviewed by Coinbase’s legal team. The call is scheduled for 30 mins, with no audience participation.  All community membe…     We have a date  Hope to see a bunch of you there for the call on Monday!
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: prose11:  If you are unhappy with the format or how this call goes, I would ask that you direct that frustration toward me as Coinbase has largely followed my suggestions on how to best do this.   You suggested to Coinbase that they pre-screen all questions and not accept any followup questions in real-time? This is a disgrace, tbh. We are Recognized Delegates of MakerDAO. We should be entitled to have a conversation with the people who are asking for 1.6 billion dollars from the DAO. What does it say about Coinbase that they won’t even give us the respect of an actual dialogue?
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: ChrisBlec:  You suggested to Coinbase that they pre-screen all questions and not accept any followup questions in real-time?   “Largely.” This was not a suggestion of mine, but a prerequisite of having a C-suite Exec being willing to appear live and answering questions. While I certainly advocate for open question formats, someone proposing an action at MakerDAO will never entitle you (Recognized Delegate status or not) to have your questions answered live by the proposal author. Authors, like every other entity operating in a DAO, have agency. I will defend every participants’ right to participate in our system as they see fit, understanding that actions have consequences and people like yourself may view anything but unfeathered access with skepticism. Appreciate the feedback as always however, if you’d like to make proposal requirements more strict happy to suggest how that might be done by proposing a MIP.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
None of the topics listed match
None of the topics listed match

content.content: prose11:  people like yourself may view anything but unfeathered access with skepticism   Coinbase is asking for 1.6 billion dollars from this DAO and is trying to use its corporate clout to put DAI at existential risk… yet it won’t engage in an open and honest conversation with its voters or delegates… and Maker’s own governance team is enabling this by filtering questions and only presenting to Coinbase what is “acceptable”. “People like myself” in this case should be every single MKR voter. This is a total embarrassment to the idea of “decentralization”. If this MIP passes without delegates even being able to openly converse with anyone from Coinbase, it will absolutely signify a point of no return for MakerDAO and DAI.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: Several MIPs go to vote with no call or call segment by the MIP authors (many notable ones since you became a Recognized Delegate). I would love to improve our batting average! But the way to do so isn’t by being unnecessarily restrictive on how that call takes place. A really important concept in building community and meaningful relationships is meeting people where they are. Coinbase (for cited compliance concerns) isn’t willing to have a free-form question call with the community, but they are willing to do this. So for a few hours of labor we get to ask the questions posed in this thread by a multitude of members of the community. You are entitled to not see that as a positive, but in my role as Governance Facilitator I have been elected by the DAO to assist in promoting good governance. That starts with meaningful discourse and debate. Being hostile to someone going beyond the minimum requirements for MIP submission is not a way to increase governance participation (an item considered crucial by most for meaningful decentralization). For weeks you were calling for Coinbase to get on a call with Maker, I understand that this was not the interaction you had in mind, however the old adage “you catch more flies with honey” comes to mind here  .
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is explaining proposal
None of the topics listed match
None of the topics listed match

content.content: I think the point is the community deserves more than some pre-screened call. This MIP, especially during this exact moment in time and considering all the surrounding circumstances, is significant. It seems to me that this call is more of a statement meant to address some of the questions. There is no audience participation. I can understand how discussing some of topics might not be a wise idea from a legal standpoint, so if the community is not satisfied with this method of disclosure they should vote accordingly. If they won’t answer the questions posted in the original thread I can’t imagine that the community will be satisfied.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: MFeinberg:  if the community is not satisfied with this method of disclosure they should vote accordingly.   This is key. MIP authors aren’t obliged to take part in an open call (or indeed any call), and voters aren’t obliged to approve of the proposal. If this method of communication by the MIP author is deemed unacceptable by a voter, that voter should communicate that through their votes.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: I agree. I think it’s important to add that while no MIP author must do a call, from what I’ve seen, most at least answer the questions, in writing, posted on the thread. I think that will be a gripe with some people and I can understand that.  Anyway, I’m looking forward to the call, I’m thankful Governance was able to set it up and I hope the call will be recorded.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal

content.content: MFeinberg:  if the community is not satisfied with this method of disclosure they should vote accordingly. If they won’t answer the questions posted in the original thread I can’t imagine that the community will be satisfied.   This particular debate, and a corresponding forum vote, should have taken place before this call was set up. GovAlpha just going ahead and setting up this call indicates an endorsement of Coinbase’s weak & tepid disclosure. Again - Coinbase wants 1.6 BILLION USDC and refuses to have an actual conversation with anybody at MakerDAO? Or has Coinbase perhaps already had enough backroom conversations with MKR whales & certain delegates to know that they have this vote on lock and they don’t feel like they need to put the proposal in peril by being open & honest? We simply don’t know. This whole thing is akin to an incumbent politician refusing to debate a new challenger simply because they don’t want to lend that challenger any credibility. No DAO should tolerate this.
GPT-discussion-categories: 3rd party giving negative feedback on proposal
3rd party giving constructive criticism of proposal
3rd party asking questions about proposal
3rd party auditing and reviewing proposal

content.content: ChrisBlec:  GovAlpha just going ahead and setting up this call indicates an endorsement of Coinbase’s weak & tepid disclosure.   Everyone is entitled to feel how they want and express that sentiment accordingly but I respectfully disagree regarding this is an endorsement of the disclosure. Again, anyone can (and should) express how they feel, I just personally don’t see this as GovAlpha endorsing anything. I think they tried to facilitate communications with the MIP author in good faith. If this is the best that the author will do, I don’t see how that can be deemed as GovAlpha condoning it. To me it’s kind of like the old saying “don’t shoot the messenger” but this is just how I personally see it.

content.content: ChrisBlec:  GovAlpha just going ahead and setting up this call indicates an endorsement of Coinbase’s weak & tepid disclosure.   I think you’re being uncharitable here, Chris. Last week, I spent 10+ minutes on a public call outlining GovAlpha’s problems with this proposal from a governance perspective. I will post an updated written version publicly in the main thread shortly. We will facilitate calls for anyone that asks us to from a position of neutrality. Would you like us to set up and facilitate a call for you where you can present your issues with this proposal in an open format?

I’d be happy to have a call with anyone who wants to discuss it. I don’t need facilitation. Coinbase’s corporate bureaucratic legalistic approach is anathema to what a DAO should be about.

content.content: Please submit my questions verbatim. A. What benefit(s) does Coinbase derive from this arrangement? Please list them all. B. Can Coinbase provide any sort of guarantee to Maker that all funds will be returned upon demand, even in the face of pressure from a government or state actor? Does Coinbase have any concern about the fact that Maker is unable to comply with OFAC sanctions?

content.content: This topic was automatically closed 91 days after the last reply. New replies are no longer allowed.
